Story: I glanced at my phone during a brief lull between stations, the screen lighting up with messages from my daughter. The family holiday was just days away, and everyone was coordinating plans, eager to hear from me. As the grandfather, I was expected to keep in touch, to reassure them I’d be there, to share in the excitement. But just as I reached for my phone, the cabin door slid open. My supervisor stepped in, clipboard in hand, eyes sharp. An unannounced audit—every move I made would be scrutinized. As a subway operator, I was expected to be flawless, focused, and strictly professional. My phone buzzed again, a photo of my grandson’s drawing popping up. My heart ached to respond, to be present for my family, but protocol demanded my undivided attention. The weight of both worlds pressed on me, each expectation pulling me in opposite directions. I stared at the controls, feeling the tension coil inside me, uncertain which role I could afford to let down.
